DOC.HEAD: Search Continues For Man Missing Since Sunday Explosion
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with second body found, heating oil prices close sharply higher, spokesman saying Exxon expects to meet its long-term commitments for heating oil. No pickup.
With AM-Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: Searchers on Tuesday found the body of a second victim of a Christmas Eve explosion at Exxon's giant refinery here that damaged buildings six miles away. Property owners, meanwhile, flooded the plant's office with calls about damage caused by the storage tank blast. Elsewhere, heating oil futures prices surged on speculation that the damage to the nation's second-largest refinery, combined with a recent record-setting cold wave, would tighten home fuel supplies. Heating oil for January delivery jumped 10.74 cents to 92.48 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Officials said they were trying to determine whether the second body was that of an Exxon worker missing since the blast. The missing worker's name has not been made public. Some workers reported seeing him Sunday after the explosion, but he has not been seen since. ``The family of the missing employee has been notified and is being updated on the status of the identification effort,'' Exxon spokesman Dave Gardner said. Previously, the company said mechanic Harold Guillory, 31, of Erwinville, an employee of a contractor, died when his pickup truck caught fire near the explosion. Exxon spokesman Jim Davis said the company didn't anticipate any immediate effect from the blast on its ability to supply heating oil. Davis said there was some flexibility in the Exxon refinery network, which includes refineries in Baytown, Texas, and Linden, N.J. Asked about long-term supplies, company spokesman Walter Eldredge said, ``We think we will be able to meet all our commitments.'' Investigators from Exxon were still working to determine the cause of the explosion. More than 1,000 Baton Rouge area residents have called Exxon with complaints that their houses were damaged by the explosion. Eldredge said Exxon officials will begin Wednesday to inspect the claimed damages. The Christmas Eve fire engulfed two large storage tanks, holding a combined 3.6 million gallons of heating oil, and three smaller tanks with about 882,000 gallons of lubricating oil, officials said. The refinery has a capacity of 455,000 barrels _ more than 19 million gallons _ of crude oil a day. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency were investigating the accident.
